title: uk earthquake surrey gatwick tremors oil fracking uk news latest
story: Dorking in Surrey has experienced 14 earthquakes since April 1 2018 (Image: )The area around Dorking in Surrey has experienced 14 earthquakes since April 1 2018, after 50 years without any tremors.Earlier this month a group of geologists called for a moratorium on oil and gas operations at nearby sites at Brockham and Horse Hill.In a statement, Vivienne Michael, leader of Mole Valley District Council, said the authority shared residents' concerns and said a link cannot be completely ruled out.She said: We have therefore been in touch with Surrey County Council (SCC), which is the mineral planning authority in this case, to ensure that they are aware of the level of concern and to urge them to take the necessary and appropriate action.                Alaska earthquake: More tremors predicted as Earth&rsquos rotation slows                Earthquake news: Earth&rsquos mantle has CRACKED leading to MORE tremorsThe earthquake issue was discussed on 8 August 2018 when county councillors approved a part-retrospective planning application by Angus Energy for a disputed oil well at Brockham.Mrs Michael said: Under National Planning Practice Guidance, the mitigation of seismic risk is one of the hydrocarbon issues that mineral planning authorities can leave to other regulatory regimes and we understand that SCC has been liaising with the Environment Agency, British Geological Survey, Health and Safety Executive and the Oil and Gas Authority as the main regulatory bodies involved.The Oil and Gas Authority (OGA) said it was difficult to see how oil and gas activities in the area could be linked to these seismic events.Since the start of the earthquakes, the British Geological Survey (BGS) has installed five seismic monitoring stations in the area.A link between earth tremors and oil drilling cannot be ruled out (Image: )But it is not yet able to say if there is a connection and there is also no timescale for its work.Mrs Michael said: We are calling on the BGS and the OGA to clarify this and to take any further action necessary to ensure that, if drilling, re-injection and flow testing are implicated, these activities are curtailed or stopped completely and our residents' concerns addressed.The statement was welcomed by local people and residents' groups.Brockham resident, Ted Kral said: The ball is now most firmly in the Oil and Gas Authority's court.I cannot understand how this Authority, having granted a temporary nationwide moratorium in 2011, following a series of significantly smaller earthquakes associated with the Preese Hall fracking site in Lancashire, has not immediately put in place a similar moratorium on oil drilling, re-injection and flow testing until more is known on possible causal links between the hydrocarbon activities and the Surrey earthquakes.This is especially after four eminent academic geologists had called for such a moratorium.We very much appreciate the council getting involved and fully support their call for further investigation and clear timescales.Ada Zaffina, of Brockham Oil Watch, said: MVDC's position is representative of the concerns of the local people, and quite different from the approach taken by Surrey County Council's planning authority during the recent meeting where permission was granted for controversial works at Brockham.SCC said that seismic risk was not a planning consideration and that it was outside of the jurisdiction of the local planning authority.We have now also asked for the available operational data for Brockham to be verified, and for detailed data held by the regulators and the operator to be released for independent analysis.                Alaska earthquake rattles volcano as US state hit by 35 tremorsJames Knapp, of the Weald Action Group, said: The statement from MVDC reflects the concerns of many Surrey residents, and is very welcome.Local group A Voice For Leith Hill has seen unprecedented demand for its earthquake edition newsletter which went to a sixth reprint, showing how widespread public concern is.The call for a moratorium by four eminent hydrocarbon geologists and seismologists was based on the coincidence of timing, depth and location of the earthquakes with activities at Brockham and Horse Hill.This merits investigation, but the OGA is conflicted as it's primary function is to promote the oil and gas industry.We are now at an an impasse.The BGS are doing their job, gathering and publishing data for others to analyse just as they did after the 2011 Preese Hall earthquakes, but no independent academic study can be made until Angus and UKOG release all borehole base pressure data and detailed logs of raw injection data including all depth, timing, quantity, pressure and fluid type.

title: water safety lyme regis couple selfie
story: The famous Cobb wall in Lyme Regis, Dorset (Image: AndrewButterfieldBNPS)The couple, who were taking selfies before the incident, were thought to be aged in their late 20s or early 30s, while the baby girl in the pram was under a year old.A witness saw the baby girl in the pram hold her arms in the air after the wave covered her on the famous Cobb wall in Lyme Regis, Dorset.Lifeboat crew member Andy Butterfield, 41, later posted on social media to warn other parents of the dangers of leaving prams unattended on the pier.He Tweeted: This is a photo of a couple with their young child in a pram on the Cobb at #LymeRegis with a wave smashing over them.                Posh mums turn pram raiders in string of shocking museum heists                UK tsunami WARNING: Devon and Cornwall hit with alert - &lsquoworst-case...They didn't appear to always be holding the pram. Why?! #RespectTheWater.The incident took place at 5.35pm on Sunday.Mr Butterfield added: It was a young couple, in their late 20s or early 30s, and they were there for some time.Just before it happened the man was taking selfies and I thought the baby, who must have been less than a year old, must have been with friends and the pram was empty.Then, this huge wave swept over and I saw the child's arms wave as she was covered by it.The pram could easily have been pushed by the wave over a large drop to the concrete below or gone the other way and been carried into the sea where it would have crashed against the sea wall.There was no good outcome there. It was shocking to witness and they are very lucky this was not a tragedy.In 2011 Clair Perkins, from Solihull, West Midlands, was killed when her electric wheelchair plunged into the sea at the Cobb.Rescuers battled to save the 21-year-old and she was pulled unconscious from the water but died in hospital.The Cobb is a 870ft long pier forming an extensive harbour and is believed to date from the the late 13th century, time of Edward I.It featured in Jane Austen's novel Persuasion and John Fowles's The French Lieutenant's Woman.

title: UK weather forecast latest hot Met Office forecast long range forecast heat September 2018
story: The mercury will rocket this weekend with 30C (86F) temperatures threatening to bake parts of the country next week.Unrelenting hot weather will ramp up the thermostat through September and possibly beyond, experts say.Southern Britain will see the best of the sunshine and drier weather with Scotland and northern England generally staying cooler and wetter.Britain is likely to stay warmer than normal through the next three months, according to the latest government long-range outlook. weather.Warmer weather will start creeping into northern Britain through the latter part of September, according to the Met Office.Spokeswoman Nicola Maxey said high pressure will build after the frost.Britons in southern and eastern regions will get the first taste of the warmer weather this weekend with thermometers poised to nudge the mid-20Cs on Sunday.Further north the mercury will hover week with highs of 23C (73.4F) forecast further north.Long-range temperature models suggest parts of Britain will remain slightly warmer than average through to the end of the year.Netweather Continent will send the mercury skyrocketing this weekend.WeatherOnline forecaster Garry Nicholson said: &ldquoHigh pressure will influence the British Isles heading into early September, bringing plenty of fair weather.&ldquoTemperatures rising, but there is uncertainty about how warm it will get - some indications draw in some very warm air from the continent by Sunday onward.&ldquoA little rain will come into the north-west at times.However the extended warm weather which kicked in during the start of spring could have a sting in the tail.While temperatures will remain high through to the end of the year, some forecasters say a severe late winter could be on the cards.Dr Todd Crawford, chief meteorologist with The Weather Company said: &ldquoWe&rsquove just experienced the warmest May-July period in many parts of northern and western Europe, including the UK.&ldquoWe expect this widespread warmth to continue into September, especially considering the relative dearth of the type of Atlantic tropical activity that could kick-start a more significant pattern change.&ldquoLooking ahead a bit into the autumn and winter, we expect warmer-than-normal temperatures to generally be the rule, especially across northern sections, in October and November.&ldquoThe very early evidence suggests that we could have some significant cold weather, however, especially in the back half of winter.

the&nbspemergency&nbspmeeting in Brussels ended without any agreement, according to the European Commission (EC).EU news: Juncker's chief spokesman praises Commission's successful legacy (Image: EUROPEAN COMMISSION)The row erupted earlier last week when Italy refused to allow 150 migrants to disembark from a ship docked in Catania.Italian officials have demanded that its EU partners agree to accept the migrants, with deputy prime minister Luigi Di Maio even threatening to withhold budget contributions to the EU.This triggered an escalating spat, with one European Commission spokesman Alexander Winterstein claiming that threats in Europe do not lead anywhere.Mr Winterstein said he did not want to go into hypothetical scenarios on what might happen if Italy doesn't pay its &pound18bn contribution.Following the deal failure, EC spokeswoman Tove Ernst added: It's a meeting where participants will contribute to bringing the ongoing joint work on solutions forward.This includes also cooperation between member states on disembarkation and responsibility sharing.You should not expect any precise decisions to be taken at the meeting today.British MEP Steven Woolfe responded to Mr Schinas' comments claiming anyone who claims Jean-Claude Juncker has saved Greece has been in the sun for too long.He told Express: Greece has 40&nbsppercent&nbspyouth unemployment, debt levels of &euro300 billion and the highest rate of suicides in the western world - whilst 35000 people have died in the Mediterranean, terrorists death squads killed hundreds across Europe and millions of illegal immigrants walked into EU unchecked.&nbspAnyone who claims Jean-Claude Juncker has saved Greece, the euro and created a holistic migration policy has clearly been in the sun too long.&nbspThe next Commission president will likely resume their role in November 2019, with Mr Juncker previously expressing his desire to step down from the top job after his five-year mandate comes to an end.&nbsp

title: the sun says philip hammond brexit gloom
story: Brexit Secretary Mr Raab rightly rubbished the wilder scare stories and said most people wouldn’t even notice the impact of a so-called “hard Brexit”.And he is convinced, like The Sun, that after a potential short-term wobble the country will be better off out.But he was realistic too about banking problems for our expats — plus credit card charges rising and customs duties having to be paid on EU imports.Why did Philip Hammond then issue a letter recycling the Treasury’s absurdly gloomy Project Fear predictions for 15 years’ time? Remainer sabotage? Or just another tone-deaf blunder?Either way, he left the Government looking even more chaotic than usual.Will No Deal happen? Consider this:Britain has offered “unconditional” security cooperation with the EU post-Brexit. In response, Brussels vows to CHARGE us to access its databases.They want capitulation, not a deal.JEREMY Corbyn’s sole motive in “changing the media” is to silence a hostile Press.The giveaway was when he attacked broadcasters yesterday for following up Sun stories. “Just because it’s on the front page of The Sun or Mail doesn’t automatically make it news,” he whined.Could this be because recent front pages have exposed Labour’s racism? That IS news, as page one stories in the two biggest daily papers tend to be.Britain already has the world’s most vibrant media. Corbyn is feigning some high-minded interest in improving it. But the last thing he wants is it holding a future Labour Government to account.He detests scrutiny, as his tantrums sparked by tricky questions prove.As for his plan for a state-run Facebook rival, can you imagine anything more ridiculous or pointless?The ­Austin Allegro of social media, making ­gargantuan losses for taxpayers?And how about his “Netflix levy” to fund the BBC?Is there no limit to the costs he wants to pile on ordinary people?NOW, by contrast, is the time for the Tories to CUT taxes.There is depressing talk of a new hike to fund the NHS. But the public finances are in unexpectedly good shape, the deficit plummeting and growth on the up.Corporation tax should be as low as Ireland’s, stamp duty slashed to get the housing market moving, fuel duty lowered, and income tax cut too.With No Deal Brexit more likely, we need to boost the economy and lure investment with a low-tax regime as never before.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: karren brady cbb dan osborne
story: The “theme” of this year’s CBB is that all the celebrities in the house have been embroiled in a scandal of some sort.But I would argue “scandal” is not quite the right word for the events that led to Osborne losing his role on Towie.In November 2014, Osborne was questioned over assault allegations after a fight with his ex, Megan Tomlin, although he was released without charge.A few months later, an audio recording emerged — allegedly secretly taken by Megan in November 2014 at her home — of Osborne apparently making foul-mouthed threats to “knife” Megan if she met another man, and referring to her as his “property”.That was three years ago, in 2015, and he went on to issue a public apology.He lost his job on Towie and also some lucrative endorsements which, no doubt, led to some soul-searching on his part.When talking about the “scandal” before entering the CBB house he said: “I said something that I never ever meant, I’m embarrassed by it. It was a horrible time.”In light of his apology, some people might talk about rehabilitation. He’s said he’s sorry and he won’t do it again.People have to be given a ­second chance — right?Before I answer that, let me flag up a few other stories that caught my eye this week.There’s the tale of Sean Simmons, 28, a domestic abuser from Hull who waterboarded one of his ex-partners, tying her to a bath before covering her face with a towel and pouring cold water over her, saying: “This is what I do to people who lie. I’m going to make you tell the truth.”Later, he produced a knife and said he’d “have to kill her”.And Darren McKie, a 43-year-old police inspector who was jailed for life after strangling his wife Leanne, 39, at their home in Cheshire, then dumping her body in a lake.And Glyn Leedell, 39, who threatened to kill a woman with a kitchen knife within hours of meeting her in a Rotherham pub.Oh, and the news that Ian Stewart, 57, who was jailed for 34 years after smothering his wife, children’s author Helen Bailey, is being questioned over the death of his first wife, Diane Stewart, who died after collapsing in the garden of the couple’s home in Cambridgeshire.I could go on, but it’s too depressing.If you read the same stories you may have taken a moment to despair that the papers are full of similar stories every day — of women being killed, brutalised and attacked by the men who purport to love them.Or, you may have barely noticed because these stories are so ­commonplace.Of course, not all men who threaten to kill their partners go on to do so.But you can be sure that most of the women above had probably suffered years of traumatic intimidation and abuse before their partners actually acted on their threats.Meanwhile, those women were ­living in fear — that’s what these chumps get off on. They want to make their victim feel helpless and powerless.So, let’s talk about forgiveness and rehabilitation.Do I think people who really regret being a perpetrator of domestic violence deserve a second chance? Yes, I do.If someone is genuinely ­repentant about anything they’ve done wrong, you can’t refuse ­forgiveness forever.Do I think that Dan Osborne’s second chance should take the form of a public platform on which to rehabilitate his image and, no doubt, earn a pretty penny or two into the bargain?No, I really, really do not.Sure, it was three years ago and no, he didn’t actually go on to act on his threat to knife his ex.But by letting him into the CBB house, Channel Five are sending a strong message that domestic violence allegations are a trivial affair, not to be taken seriously.By welcoming him in, despite his “scandal”, they are normalising and turning a blind eye to the kind of behaviour that too often ruins — and sometimes ends — women’s lives.People on TV are role models. And to allow a man who has made verbal threats to kill his girlfriend to become a role model is irresponsible in the extreme.ITV recognised this when they decided to boot him off Towie.Channel Five should have done the same.SHIRLEY BALLAS has revealed she weighs herself every day in the run up to Strictly in order to get “telly ready”.You might think that sounds extreme but, believe me, the only way to get telly ready is to take very seriously the old adage that the screen adds a stone.I don’t exactly weigh myself before filming The Apprentice or Give It A Year but, in the three months leading up to filming, I always manage to lose – by hook or by crook – a stone.In fact we all do – Lord Sugar and Claude Littner are watching what they eat as well.Then, as soon as filming stops, we all immediately put the weight back on again as normal life resumes.And, let me tell you, it’s a lot harder to take it off than it is to put it on.I’M a big believer in benefits being available to people who need help because they can’t help themselves.But the story of Bangladeshi immigrant Abdul Jalil, a father of six who came to the UK in 1969, really makes a mockery of the system.Jalil, who is 64, hasn’t worked since 1988 for “health reasons”.But a probation officer found the only problem he had is a slightly tender right knee.In 2008, he exceeded the amount of cash that claimants are allowed to have when he was loaned £25,000 to buy his council house.He did not notify the Department for Work and Pensions and continued wrongly claiming more than £28,000 over the next eight years.He then lied to the DWP about his assets as he filled out his benefits review form in 2012.He had re-mortgaged his council flat in May that year for roughly £148,000 and given the money to his children so they could purchase their own properties keeping around £86,500 for himself.Then at court this week he was spared jail – in favour of community service and even had the cheek to say he would do it if it was “light work”.I know that some people need benefits to get back on their feet, and I’m proud to live in a country that provides that.But once a person is back up, they need to actually stand on their own two feet – rather than abusing the system that helped them.Like all benefit cheats, he should pay the money back or go to jail and never be allowed access to benefits again.AS taxpayers we give almost £14BILLION a year away in foreign aid of which almost £1billion goes to the EU, and this week the Government was threatening to withdraw our cash if there was no-deal Brexit.Why wait until Brexit? Just stop it now.We need this money to fix our own country – our NHS, our police forces, our schools, benefits and housing all need it desperately.And the worst part of all this is that we have to borrow the money to give it away.Our country has almost £2TRILLION of debt, which costs around £50billion a year to service in interest.Borrowing money to give it away, it’s the economics of the madhouse.I KNOW our prisons are full, but it beggars belief that Allan Williamson, 45, was let off with a two-year community order and 30 days rehabilitation.When police raided his flat in Hulme, Manchester, they found more than 600 images – including 68 films classed as Category A, the highest level of children being sexually abused.To be clear, the images showed children as young as seven being sexually abused by adults.Still, Judge Elizabeth Nicholls,  decided prison wasn’t necessary, saying Williamson had been “open and frank” with the police about his behaviour and because the man has allegedly taken “tentative steps to address these issues”.So the guy was in possession of 600 images including many of the worst kind of paedophilia – and he’s still in the community?Who in their right mind would want this guy in their community?I know the prisons are buckling, so let’s just build more – even if that includes sending prisoners out to sea in containers.When is the justice system going to start thinking about the victims as opposed to the perpetrators?I BET the boyfriend of Kay Longstaff – the air hostess who spent ten hours in the water after plunging from a cruise liner – is feeling a bit embarrassed.Longstaff was miraculously rescued ten hours after falling – or jumping – from the Norwegian Star, 60 miles off the Croatian coast last week.It’s not quite clear what happened beforehand but other passengers and crew claim to have seen Ms Longstaff in several arguments with her partner Craig Rayment, above with Kay, on the evening of the incident.Once she’d been rescued, Mr Rayment’s estranged wife Kelly offered Ms Longstaff some unsolicited support, saying: “If I was on a ship with him, I would get off any way I could.”Oh dear.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: politicians dont answer questions
story: I have made my peace with this and accepted, regardless of the fact I have never fiddled my expenses or taken cash for ­questions, some of those who come before me have damned all politicians to the sin-bin.I do, however, think there is one very simple thing all politicians could agree to do that would help rehabilitate us to the public.We could answer a straight question with a straight answer.This week doing the rounds on Twitter was a clip of Jeremy Corbyn on Channel 4 News being asked six times: “Do you honestly believe Britain will be better off outside of the EU?”Each time he answered with a iation of, “Labour wants to maintain good relations with the EU to protect jobs”.His words are not bad — it is certainly the answer he and his team would have practised.But it is not an answer to that question and that’s the problem.To the average punter it just looks like politicians can’t be straight.The answer, as far as I’m concerned, is a big fat no.Gavin Williamson, the Defence Secretary, suffered a similar cringeworthy encounter with Richard Madeley in May.The question in the wake of the Salisbury poisonings was: “You told Russia to ‘shut up and go away’.Do you regret that now?Do you think it was too informal?”He started by answering an entirely different question about paying tribute to healthcare workers, which had absolutely nothing to do with what he was being asked.God only knows why he didn’t just say: “Yeah, it wasn’t my finest hour but I guess I was just really cross that people in Britain were being poisoned.”He could then have gone on to say all the nice things about Salisbury health workers.Instead, Madeley savaged him and all that anyone remembers of the encounter is that Gavin Williamson should avoid interviews.Mind you, at least both Corbyn and Williamson gave an answer.At least they bothered to take part.Boris Johnson would just have offered his questioner a cup of tea as if he was Mrs Doyle from Father Ted.I honestly despair.I’m not sure when the art of just repeating the same message over and over again, even if it in no way answers the question, started.Most people put it down to the Tony Blair years of slick media management, but times have surely got to move on.Politicians spend too much time hedging their bets, trying to keep all the people happy and end up pleasing no one by waffling through an answer that is basically six of one and half a dozen of the other.I get that it is hard when your job is basically a massive popularity contest, but I am not sure we are made more popular by dodging questions and refusing to give our own opinions.People contact me every single week telling me they don’t always agree with me but they appreciate that I stand up for what I believe.I honestly don’t think the British people want politicians to say an approximation of a safe answer, or to try to be pals with everyone.People have a damn sight more respect for people when they say what they think, even if they disagree.For too long politicians have been especially scared of upsetting working-class people, without recognising that most people don’t even think of themselves that way any more.I have absolutely no idea where the idea came from that the average member of the public can’t stand a bit of discussion and disagreement, or are so fragile that they will all fall apart if someone says something not to their liking.I have never once voted for someone who I agreed with 100 per cent of the time.I didn’t marry someone I agreed with a 100 per cent of the time and, frankly, if he tried to please me, placate me and pander to all my views I would no longer stay married to him, because it would be dishonest.Don’t get me wrong — saying what you think is not a universally appreciated characteristic and some do get in touch with me to tell me to shut up and go away.Much like Russia probably felt when Williamson said it to them, I pay little mind to this and crack on.Journalists do sometimes ask stupid questions.Politicians do have to be careful about what they say as it can sometimes get twisted and misrepresented.Things are not always simple, and giving a quick answer on a complex issue takes some skill.All that said, it has got to be time to stop the waffle and give the public a break from shouting at their telly each night: “For God’s sake, answer the bleedin’ question!”IT’S that time of year where slow news weeks turn to how much wine we should drink and if swearing at work should be banned.Apparently no amount of alcohol is safe, which will change absolutely no one’s behaviour, and swearing at work is bad for morale.I cannot agree on the swearing front.I am not advocating we all run around barking sweary orders and aggressive expletives at our colleagues but I find sometimes, especially in times of high stress in the office, nothing will quite explain it like a collective FFS.I have seen how a bit of good old Anglo Saxon can be used to break down barriers between me and my constituents.It stops me seeming like some lofty bureaucrat who cannot understand their problems.In some cases it makes them physically relax if we get a bit sweary about their crappy landlord or their benefits being stopped.We all swear, and most of us drink, I doubt that’s going to change.PADDY DOHERTY of My Big Fat Gypsy Wedding and Celeb Big Brother fame was in the papers this week, leading the funeral procession for his nephew.A sad affair, of course, but the diamond-encrusted funeral casket is reported to have cost £100,000.I remember organising my own mother’s funeral and balking at spending around £2,500 for an event I’d rather have not had to attend.I could hear her voice in my head saying, “How much?” as we wrote out cheques for cars and coffins. My wedding only cost £3k and I thought that was a bit much.When my time comes, I implore my family to keep their cash. I wouldn’t be thankful for money being literally burnt.THIS week’s, in fact this year’s, feminist icon goes to the unlikely Stormy Daniels.There is, of course, no reason why feminism would not extend to women performing in pornography but there are few crossovers.Stormy Daniels is a hero.World leaders across the globe pander to Trump, few are brave enough to publicly call out his racism, sexism and terrible decision making.Our own PM holds his hand, allowing him to make her look weak and feeble.Ms Daniels has been brave enough not only to take on the most powerful man in the world but also some pretty tooled-up lawyers too.After apparently receiving payment and signing a non-disclosure agreement to hush her up about an affair she had with Trump in 2006, she broke rank.This was not just a kiss and tell, this was a story that has caused Donald Trump’s lawyer Michael Cohen to plead guilty to breaking election campaign rules.He explicitly stated that he was told to pay her the money by “the candidate” meaning Trump. Donald Trump will probably get away with this misdemeanour, but it is the closest he has come to being in real trouble.Without Stormy Daniels and her courage to face down legal threats, vicious hate mail and a campaign to discredit her, powerful men would continue to use women as playthings and just pay them off when they are done.Stormy Daniels is every woman who has been messed about and we salute her for fighting back.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: just ignore bogus chancellor hammond the sun is brexing out
story: Of course, she was right to ask.Not a single public authority predicted the biggest crash in modern history — not the Bank of England, not the ­Treasury, and certainly not the Chancellor of the Exchequer.Then in 2016 they did it again. Project Fear forecast dramatic downturns in the economy if the people were so unwise as to vote for Brexit. Wrong again.Since then, we have had record levels of employment, huge investments from the likes of Google, Microsoft, SoftBank and a long list of other companies.They demonstrated their confidence in the future of this great country in the best way possible — with their money.This time round the wise insight came from Andy Haldane, the best economist at the Bank of England.Ruefully he said “economic forecasting is having a Michael Fish moment”.Michael Fish was the weather forecaster who completely mispredicted the huge 1987 storm that struck Britain.If only economic forecasters were even as good as weather forecasters, we would be a lot better off. But they are not, and they are at it again.This week Chancellor Philip Hammond predicted the Treasury would need to raise an extra £80billion in 15 years’ time in the event of a no-deal Brexit.And yet the Chancellor insists on ­trotting out yet another bogus forecast, on the very day that my successor as Brexit Secretary, Dominic Raab, is ­presenting the first set of preparation for no deal.Coincidence? I do not think so.The great departments of state are very careful about what they put in the public domain, and exactly when.For nobody is this more true than the Treasury, which has to judge the public perception of everything it does, if only because of its effect on the markets. So this was either spectacularly incompetent, or deliberate. I know what I think.And even more disgraceful, by doing so it will undermine the Government’s hand in striking a deal with the EU.If they do not think we dare walk away, then they will give us the worst deal they can think of. Bear in mind that the Chequers deal already concedes enormous amounts to the EU.It would not be long before our world-leading position in life sciences, gene technology, artificial intelligence, self-driving cars and a whole range of other modern industries would be being actively undermined by the Europeans.As for being out of reach of the ­European Court, pull the other one.But now the Treasury is beginning to fear that even these spectacular concessions the Government has made in the Chequers deal will not deliver agreement from the European Commission — or if it does, the Commons will turn it down.In that event you can expect attempts by the Remainers in Parliament to try to scupper our departure by delaying it beyond the General Election, or offer some other enormous raft of concessions to give back control of the EU.Hence the ridiculous suggestion that the Army would be used to move food around the country.Why? What conceivable aspect of European policy would handicap British hauliers moving British products from Kent to Cumbria?None of course, but it was just the bogus nonsense some of our Remainer media is only too happy to carry ­completely uncritically. Similarly, we have heard suggestions of all sorts of shortages, based it seems mostly on the idea that the French might impede the flow of goods between Calais and Dover.It would not be the first time we had dealt with such issues. We had about 30 days of such delays in 2015. I remember queues of lorries, but I do not remember shortages of food or medicines.And on other issues, are the Europeans really going to pick a fight on data with the biggest IT power on the continent, on banking are they going to refuse to cooperate with the greatest financial ­centre in the world?Are the Greeks, Italians and Spaniards going to disadvantage the UK residents on whom many of their local economies depend? Or stop tourism? I think not.I suspect we are quite likely to have the odd hiccup when we leave the EU, but we will be able to cope, which is what Dominic Raab was demonstrating this week. And any problems we have will be over in months not years.So in 15 years’ time, far from worrying about Mr Hammond’s £80billion bill, the country will have trouble remembering what all the fuss was about.The biggest question will be whether we have made the most of the opportunities created by Brexit.And that is what we should worry about today, creating the circumstances where this great country can take its proper place in the world. We will only be able to do that if we allow ourselves the freedoms a clean Brexit will deliver.So my advice to all my old colleagues in Cabinet is simple: Ignore the misery merchants of the Treasury, stop fearing things that will never happen, and start planning for the real opportunities that this great country can grasp when it sets its mind to it.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: randy dolphin rubbing itself against swimmers sparks beach ban in french resort loved by brit tourists
story: The mayor of Landevennec, in Brittany, has outlawed bathing and diving from the districts beaches whenever the horny animal is spotted.The move came after after the visibly excited three-metre  dolphin - nicknamed Zafar - rubbed himself up against boats and bathers.I issued the decree to ensure safety... Several bathers were really afraid. He even lifted up a woman bather with his snout, mayor Roger Lars told the local newspaper Ouest France.The dolphin has been hanging around the Bay of Brest for months, swimming near the beaches of Plougastel-Daoulas, Logonna-Daoulas and Landevennec.He likes to frolic around tourist boats and even lets swimmers grip onto his dorsal fin and go for a ride with him, but recently he has become just a little too friendly.Locals have told of the sexed-up mammals antics, with several going into some detail about shocked tourists being confronted with the animal’s sexual arousal.Experts say dolphins appear to have frequent recreational sex and sometimes display sexual behaviour towards other species - including humans.They point out that they are very large wild animals and could cause serious injury - even inadvertently with a flipper - if they feel in any way threatened.But attacks or injury to humans by dolphins are so rare that a Breton lawyer says he plans to take legal action to have what he calls the “excessive” swimming ban flipped.“The mayor wants to make dolphins look like almost ferocious beasts, completely unpredictable and likely to drown people,” said Erwan Le Cornec.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: the sun says theresa may trade deals africa
story: A major factor of the Leave vote was for Britain to become an independent nation, free to strike global trade deals with fast-growing, emerging economies.So the Prime Minister is absolutely right to start outlining trade policy with our Commonwealth allies South Africa, Nigeria and Kenya.She is also right to call for funds from our bloated foreign aid budget to be diverted from frivolous handouts and used instead on developing infrastructure and security in Africa.As we unshackle ourselves from Brussels, it is clear Africa presents us with huge opportunities.It is the world’s second biggest continent, home to 16 per cent of the global population. Its GDP is growing rapidly. Similar to India, its middle classes are rocketing. And its workforce is estimated to be larger than China’s by 2035.Over 17 millions Brits voted for a Brexit that would make us a freer, richer country.This is exactly the type of buccaneering move that will make that vision a reality.THE EU’s threats regarding a No Deal Brexit are total bluster.The bloc claims there will be chaos if we leave without a deal, that the impact on trade and travel will be so severe we will crawl back to the negotiating table.But behind closed doors, the EU admits this is codswallop.The EU Commission has drawn up secret No Deal plans that are “very similar” to Britain’s Brexit preparation.In other words, in the event of a No Deal they will keep things almost exactly the same because they don’t want to be hit.What a surprise.WHEN will Labour moderates realise their party is beyond repair?Jewish Labour MPs need bodyguards for the party conference next month. There is a backlog of anti-Semitism complaints that could take YEARS to probe. And their leader is an ­anti-Semitic IRA-apologist, who counts the former BNP leader and the KKK among his cheerleaders.By staying in the party, Labour MPs signal that they want Corbyn to be PM.No amount of tribal loyalty can make them think that is a good idea.IT is shocking that deadly diet pills are being brazenly flogged on Instagram.The Facebook-owned company must better protect youngsters.It should hire a proper workforce to establish oversight of what is put online.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: jeremy hunt myanmar visit un genocide report
story: The Foreign Secretary described the report as “deeply disturbing” and said there should “never be a hiding place for those who commit these kind of atrocities”.Investigators working for the UN’s top human rights body took the unusual step of identifying six military leaders by name among those behind what they called deadly, systematic crimes against the ethnic minority.The call amounts to some of the strongest language yet from UN officials who have denounced alleged human rights violations in Myanmar  since a bloody crackdown began last August.Mr Hunt tweeted: “Deeply disturbing to read UN report on crimes against Rohingya people.“There must be never be a hiding place for those who commit these kind of atrocities.Have decided to visit Burma to seek answers at the earliest opportunity.”The three-member “fact-finding mission” and their team, working under a mandate from the UN-backed Human Rights Council, meticulously assembled hundreds of accounts from expatriate Rohingya, as well as satellite footage and other information to assemble the report.“The military’s contempt for human life, dignity and freedom, for international law in general, should be a cause of concern for the entire population of Myanmar, and to the international community as a whole,” fact-finding mission chair Marzuki Darusman, a former Indonesian attorney-general, told a news conference.The council created the mission in March last year, nearly six months before a string of deadly rebel attacks on security and police posts set off a crackdown that drove Rohingya to flee into neighbouring Bangladesh.More than 700,000 people are thought to have fled, according to UN estimates.The team compiled accounts of crimes including gang rape, the torching of hundreds of villages, enslavement, and killings of children, some before the eyes of their own parents.But it was not granted access to Myanmar and has decried a lack of co-operation or even response from the government, which received an early copy of the report.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: theresa may bag charge hammond
story: The PM is due to unveil the move this week - and also roll out the levy to smaller retailers.The 5p charge has led to a dramatic 86 per cent drop in plastic bag use at the UK’s seven major supermarkets since the scheme was introduced.Treasury insiders have said the PMs attempt to hike the charge to 10p is unnecessary and will appear like the Government is trying to profit from the charge.The fresh spat comes the day after The Sun revealed that Mr Hammond had clashed with Environment Secretary Michael Gove over other green taxes including proposals for a levy on disposable coffee cups.Revealing yet another clash between the Chancellor and No10, a Treasury source told the Daily : The 5p tax has already worked and dramatically reduced the use of plastic bags.If its raised to 10p it looks like profiteering.The key thing is that people feel their family budget is going up.Consumers dont want to feel like they are being hammered with more taxes on the cost of everyday living.There were more than 7.6 billion single-use bags used in 2014 but last year that had fallen to just 1.7 billion.Consumers dont want to feel like they are being hammered with more taxes on the cost of everyday living.There were more than 7.6 billion single-use bags used in 2014 but last year that had fallen to just 1.7 billion.That represents a drop from Brits using around 140 bags every year that generated 61,000 tonnes of waste, to around 20 bags.Yesterday The Sun revealed that Mr Hammond had privately blasted Mr Gove’s radical approach to cutting plastic waste - arguing that it wrongly targets consumers.Mr Hammond has told Treasury insiders that he’s “not interested” in creating new taxes such as the a 25p on disposable coffee cups backed by the Environment Secretary earlier this year.Mr Gove described the so-called ‘latte levey’ as an “exciting idea” and also claimed the British public were “prepared to pay more in order to help the environment”.In a dig at Mr Gove, Mr Hammond told friends that he wants to take a “more intelligent” approach such as using “very small but significant tax incentives” on producers and retailers.He believes this approach would force businesses to “take more responsibility over the products they choose rather than increasing taxes on consumers,” a source close to the Chancellor said.The source told The Sun: “The Chancellor takes the view that we’re not particularly excited about creating new taxes like coffee cup taxes and so on, which are just going to hit working people.“We’re much more interested in if we can do something that we think is more intelligent that is very small but significant tax incentives on the retailers and producers which will make them change behaviour and hopefully not hurt customers at all.”The Treasury insider added: “There are more systemic ways to change the system and get retailers and producers to take more responsibility over the products they choose rather than increasing taxes on consumers, which at the end of the day means more money for hardworking people when they shop in the supermarket. That’s our approach.”Mr Hammond’s attack on Mr Gove follows a similar rebuke by his deputy Liz Truss, who used a speech in June to openly mock Mr Gove over his nanny state crackdown on disposable cups, plastic straws and wood-burning stoves.Earlier this month the Treasury signalled it would announce a new “plastic tax” on firms selling single-use water bottles, takeaway boxes and coffee cups.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: khalid mahmood elaina cohen settlement expenses
story: Khalid Mahmood, the shadow foreign minister for Europe, was taken to an employment tribunal by his assistant and former lover Elaina Cohen.The case was settled out of court but Mr Mahmoods legal expenses was covered by the taxpayer-funded expenses system, according to the Daily .He also claimed £37,000 to pay for extra staff, partly to cover while Ms Cohen was absent during the tribunal.Jeremy Corbyns office was made aware of the case, the newspaper reported - raising fresh questions about the Labour leaders handling of his partys anti-Semitism crisis.Ms Cohen told the Daily : I complained to Ipsa several times on the unfairness of substantial public funds being used.Ipsa should not be funding MPs in actions against their members of staff.Were in the middle of an anti-Semitism storm, and I had two years of hell over two tweets trying to bring it to the partys attention.Sir Alistair Graham, the former chairman of the committee on standards in public life, said: “If public money is involved, there should not be secret deals like non-disclosure agreements used to resolve staff issues. This is about transparency.”The pair were previously caught claiming for luxury hotel stays when they were lovers over ten years ago.A spokesman for Ipsa said: “MPs may apply for a contingency payment for costs which are not covered by the [MPs’ expenses] scheme or where they expect to exceed a particular budget.“Applications are considered by the Contingency Panel who assess whether there are exceptional circumstances warranting extra support.”

title: theresa may insists no deal brexit would not be the end of the world
story: Speaking as she arrived in South Africa this morning for a trade visit, the Prime Minister said it was important to let Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab unveil the Governments contingency plans for crashing out of the EU without a trade deal in place.Her words came after the Chancellor was accused of attempting to derail the planning through scaremongering.Last Wednesday Mr Hammond sparked uproar from fellow ministers and Tory MPs after publishing a doom-laden warning that Britain would face an £80 billion hike in borrowing in a No Deal scenario on the same day Mr Raab set out the first tranche of Whitehall emergency plans.The Chancellor rehashed highly contentious Treasury analysis of what would happen if talks with Brussels collapsed and Britain moved to trading with our nearest neighbours on tariff rules set out by the World Trade Organisation.But speaking for the first time on the row, Mrs May sided with Mr Raab in the latest Cabinet split and echoed claims from the head of the WTO that No Deal would not be a walk in the park, but it wouldnt be the end of the world.She added that Mr Raabs sweeping plans would make sure if we are in that situation we can make a success of it.And she repeatedly stressed that the divisive Treasury figures leaked at the beginning of the year - dubbed Project Fear 2 by Brexiteers - were not a complete look at the state of Brexit, despite her own Chancellor still publicly relying on them.Mrs May hit out: The figures were a work in progress at the time, what is important is what we do as Government is we negotiate with the EU on the deal, which we think will be a good deal, at the same time recognising that we dont know what the outcome of those negotiations will be.Speaking to journalists on board her RAF flight to South Africa, Mrs May added: What is important from a UK point of view, is that this wont be a walk in the park, but it wouldnt be the end of the world.The slap down for the Chancellor came as Mrs May began a three day tour of South Africa, Nigeria and Kenya to drum up post-Brexit investment in the Commonwealth.Speaking for the first time since her summer holiday, Mrs May also:Mrs May told reporters: What we are doing is we are working to get a good and I am confident we are able to to get a good deal but of course it is also absolutely right that as a government we make preparations for all potential outcomes.That is why we have published the technical notices in relation to No Deal. and we are ensuring our preparations are going alongside the important negotiations.And she vowed to continue talks with continental leaders alongside official negotiations with Brussels ahead of an impromptu EU summit early next month in Salzburg, Austria.

title: pontins guest given wrong apartment key
story: The Brean Sands holiday park in Burnham-On-Sea, Somerset, has been bombarded with bad reviews and horror stories this summer.A Birmingham Live reporter spent 24 hours at Pontins and revealed she was kept up at night by family arguments and was given keys to someone else’s room.She also faced overflowing litter bins, chewing gum trodden into carpets and vomit on stairs leading to chalets.A horrified dad even showed her a duvet smeared with poo that he had to fork out £8 for - and then had to wait from 4pm until 11pm for clean bed linen for his children.The reporter said: I’m first greeted to my apartment block with the sight of what appears to be someone’s vomit. I try to dodge this as I haul my suitcase up the steps.After she got to her apartment, she was met with empty booze crates, two damp towels and a full to the brim bin - only to discover it was already being occupied by another family.The buffet dinner, which costs £8.95, included spots of food from previous meals and overwhelming smells, the reporter claims.She was also woken up at 3am by families rowing and a child is said to have slashed her foot on a broken tile in the swimming pool.And the holiday was also ruined by technical faults - meaning some of the attractions were not available - and a fire alarm in the early hours of the morning.Some guests even cleaned their apartments themselves because the smell was like rot, damp, festering bodies.The holiday park opened in 2011 and charges £139 for two nights in a one-bed apartment – with electricity at an extra cost.Pontins have been approached for comment.Spare key to somebodys apartmentTo my surprise the key worked, but as I tried to enter, a rubbish bag full of half-eaten food and cans erupted and spilled out - blocking the entrance.New apartment damp and reeks of smokeBuffet on dirty platesDoors banging, kids screamingChild cuts foot on broken pool tileFaeces smothered on duvet

title: home bargains lorry driver rams car motorway
story: Dashcam footage shows the lorry swerve dangerously from the second to third lane – forcing a silver Ford Fiesta to veer across two lanes and onto the hard shoulder to avoid colliding with the HGV.But the red and blue Home Bargains lorry driver seems unfazed - and the lorry again swerves shakily back into the second lane before coming to a sudden stop with its hazard warning lights flashing.The silver Ford Fiesta halts in the lane beside it as other vehicles -including a van painted with the Union Jack, are forced to swing around the now stationary lorry.The video – filmed as the lorry heads towards junction 44 on the A1M North in Yorkshire – has been posted to the Facebook group Idiot UK Drivers Exposed.After almost causing a serious accident, the clip then shows the lorry as it continues its journey along the left lane for the A64 towards Leeds and York.The motorist who captured the footage then overtook the lorry, and continued onto the A1.They said: My lane is left for the A64! I wanted to get passed this nutter thats why I got by him!The clip currently has more than 106,000 views.A spokeswoman for Home Bargains described the driving in the video as totally unacceptable and confirmed the driver has been suspended pending further investigation.She added: “The lorry shown in the dash cam footage was being driven by one of our contractors. Clearly the driving shown in the video is totally unacceptable.We are currently looking into the incident with the contractor concerned. In the meantime, the driver has been suspended pending further investigation.We would like to apologise to the drivers of the cars involved, we recognise it must have been a very frightening experience and also thank the Sun and the car drivers for bringing this to our attention.”

title: women march topless new york equal rights
story: The mobilisation, known as Go Topless Day, encouraged protesters to unhinge their bras and free their nipples while proudly march through the streets in public.Some women can be seen holding protest signs, giving out leaflets and declaring that “war is obscene, not my nipples”.Pictures emerged showing half-naked women walking through Midtown Manhattan as they fight for their right to go topless in public.Although all protesters were welcomed to fully expose the breasts, there were some chose to cover their nipples with tape or body paint.Some of the them carried posters with phrases like Free the nipple, Your body is not a mistake or Lets make the body normal again.A pink breast-shaped balloon can be seen being put up on top of a car as it drive along with the protesters.The New York City police has blocked off the parade route for full safety while the supporters enjoyed the scantily-clad event.On its 11th celebration, this year’s march fell on August 26, which marked as the Women’s Equality Day.The organisation explained that it was the day when women earned their rights to vote on the basis of Gender Equality in 1920.The event was also held in the Netherlands, Germany, Canada, France, Chile and South Korea.“As long as men are allowed to be topless in public, women should have the same constitutional right,” said Maitreya Rael, who inspired the creation of Go Topless in 2007.According to Go Topless, states such as Utah and Indiana considered the showing of female breasts as an indecent act and offenders can be arrested for “disorderly conduct”.

title: raf photo of the year 2018 centenary
story: Over 1,000 pictures and 25 videos were entered to this years competition with subjects ranging from Spitfires and Lancaster Bombers to Typhoons and Chinooks with the best nine now going head-to-head online in the Peoples Choice category.The judging for this years competition recently took place at the RAF Museum in London with three professional judges choosing the best nine images.Now its up to the public to choose their favourite photo with the winner to be announced on Thursday 20th September at a special ceremony.The awards ceremony is set to take place at Bentley Priory Museum which served as RAF Fighter Command during the Battle of Britain.The annual competition was set up to celebrate the achievements of the RAF and was open to the general public for the first time this year.The RAF, established during the end of the First World War, is the oldest institution of its kind in the world.Before the RAFs foundation in 1918 both the Army and Royal Navy had their own air corps with the Royal Flying Corps founded in 1912.You can visit the RAFs website to cast your vote.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: iceland worker puts coat around dog
story: The small dog had been left outside by its owner but when it began pouring with rain Luke Carlin, a 19-year-old Iceland worker, took pity and covered it with his jacket.The heart-warming moment was filmed by an onlooker from inside their car and the video has now been viewed 2.6million times on Facebook.In the clip, filmed from a car parked outside the Finaghy Iceland, a small, grey, hairy dog looks miserable as its tied to a post outside in the rain.Luke can be seen walking out of the Iceland store, fleece in hand, before he gently places it on top of the dog and readjusts it to shelter the pup from the rain.The teenager, from Belfast, told Belfast Live: The owner was just nipping into the chemist then all of a sudden the rain started.Me and a girl who works with me saw the dog, so we agreed to put the jacket over it.Then shortly after another girl from my work brought the dog out of the rain.The reaction has been so crazy I thought it would have maybe peaked at a few hundred likes on the video when I first initially seen it.Stephen, who filmed the event, said: It’s been crazy how fast it went viral and I didn’t expect it in anyway but I guess it shows how much people appreciate a genuine act of kindness no matter what it is!The original Facebook video shared by Stephen McIntosh has over 6,200 comments. One Facebook user, Ricky Mead commented: Well done chap you are one of the better humans to roam this magnificent planet.Katie Alkaradi also commented in support of Luke, writing: this is one of the kindest things Ive ever seen. While Savannah Chelsea commented, not all heroes wear capes!!

title: bono wave eu flags u2 gigs pro europe
story: The multi-millionaire frontman was mocked after he claimed celebrating the EU is transgressive and a radical act.The bizarre gesture is intended as a statement of support for Brussels in the wake of Brexit and Eurosceptic movements around the continent.Bono, who is known for his political activism and charity work, revealed his plans in an article for German newspaper Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung.He wrote, Im told a rock band is at its best when it’s a little transgressive: when it pushes the bounds of so-called good taste, when it shocks, when it surprises.Well, U2 is kicking off its tour in Berlin this week, and we’ve just had one of our more provocative ideas: during the show we’re going to wave a big, bright, blue EU flag.The singer admitted his plan sounds kitsch - but insisted its actually a radical act because of Brexit and other anti-EU movements.He claimed his home country of Ireland had gained greater power through being part of the EU.And praising the values which are supposed to underpin the EU, Bono concluded: That idea of Europe deserves songs written about it, and big bright blue flags to be waved about.To prevail in these troubled times Europe is a thought that needs to become a feeling.Bono, 58, has been active in politics for decades and is close to leaders such as Tony Blair and George W. Bush.But his latest wheeze was derided by U2 fans who urged him to stick to the music on the bands upcoming tour.One British fan, Ruth Fryman, said: I prefer to choose my own causes. Hell get short shrift waving that flag here in the UK!

title: reading festival idiot films himself jumping tents
story: The mindless clown has been labelled a loser and an attention seeker by Twitter users after he shared the footage.The video shows the man, who has not been named, lunging into ious tents in a bid to take them down as a music festival drew to a close.Sharing the footage, he wrote: If this was your tent I don’t apologise.He then added: If anyone has a problem dm I’ll come meet you for a scrap.After taking down the third tent, he bragged that he had completed a hattrick before going on to take out more.However despite his attempt to show off, he has been universally slammed on Twitter.One user said: Imagine someone was in that tent and you seriously injured them for 400 likes on a video for Twitter??Another said: I actually feel sorry for you.Got no personality so you have to do things like this to try and look good. Were you not given enough attention as a child?He was also branded rude and irresponsible, by one who added: Making other peoples lives more difficult is never funny or clever.Grow up.Others branded him mindless and a loser.It is not known which festival the stunt took place at - however the video was uploaded this weekend during Reading and Leeds festival.

title: theresa may brexit better off second referendum
story: The Prime Minister was asked SIX times if she thinks the UK can thrive even with No Deal - and if she would vote for Brexit in a second referendum.But she declined to answer the question - insisting that she is focussed on cutting a trade deal with Europe.Mrs Mays ministers last week laid out No Deal plans which are designed to help the UK cope with the potential collapse of talks with Brussels.But when asked if the proposals would be enough to ensure that Britain is better off after Brexit no matter what the outcome, the PM wouldnt reply.During a visit to South Africa, she said to Sky News: What were working for with the European Union is a good deal.Of course its right because we dont know the outcome of the negotiations that we prepare for No Deal.Asked a second time, Mrs May insisted there were huge opportunities open to the United Kingdom after Brexit, adding: What the Government is working for is to ensure that whatever the outcome of the negotiations, we make a success of leaving the European Union.After she ignored the question twice more, the PM was asked whether shed vote Leave if there was a re-run of the referendum.She again dodged the issue, saying: That is a hypothetical question, and I dont answer hypothetical questions because were not in the business of having - and its very important this point - because were not in the business of having a second referendum on Brexit.What were in the business of doing is delivering Brexit, so actually what someone would vote for today is not the issue.Pressed a second time, Mrs May again refused to answer.The PMs dodge comes a week after Jeremy Corbyn similarly refused to say whether he believed the UK will be better off after Brexit.Both leaders campaigned for Remain in the referendum but have committed to respecting the result of the vote in 2016.Critics mocked Mrs May for avoiding the crucial question - Lib Dem MP Tom Brake, who backs the Peoples Vote campaign, said: “We are in the unprecedented and unenviable situation of having a Prime Minister who clearly does not believe that her own Government’s flagship policy – Brexit – is in the best interests of the country.And yet she insists on inflicting it on us all anyway.

The answer is yes - this government is delivering it."Mrs May also refused to be drawn on a warning from her former foreign secretary, Boris Johnson, that her Chequers proposal would risk harming Britain's economy.She said simply that the proposed plan for a future relationship with Brussels would be a "a good deal for the UK" and "a good deal for the EU". title: former chief rabbi says jeremy
story: NewsFormer chief Rabbi says Jeremy Corbyn's 'Zionist' comments were the most offensive made by a senior British politician since 'Rivers of Blood'Jonathan Sacks described the Labour leader as an "anti-Semite" who has given support to "racists, terrorists and dealers of hate"Share&nbsp&nbspCommentsByJason BeattieHead of politics18:09, 28 AUG 2018Updated18:44, 28 AUG 2018NewsIt was the harshest criticism of Jeremy Corbyn to date "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailJeremy Corbyn was compared to Enoch Powell and branded an “anti-Semite” by a former chief Rabbi for his controversial comments on Zionism. Jonathan Sacks said the Labour leader’s remarks were to the “most offensive statement” made by senior politician since Powell’s 1968 Rivers of Blood speech. Lord Sacks spoke out after video from 2013 emerged of Mr Corbyn saying “British Zionists” didn’t “understand English irony.” The Labour leader has insisted his remarks were taken out of context and he did not used the word Zionist as “a euphemism for Jewish people.” But Lord Sacks, the chief Rabbis from 1991 to 2013, said his comments were “divisive” and “hateful.”  “The recently disclosed remarks by Jeremy Corbyn are the most offensive statement made by a senior British politician since Enoch Powell’s 1968 ‘Rivers of Blood’ speech.   “It was divisive, hateful and like Powell’s speech it undermines the existence of an entire group of British citizens by depicting them as essentially alien,” Lord Sacks told the New Statesman magazine. He added: “We can only judge Jeremy Corbyn by his words and his actions. “When he implies that, however long they have lived here, Jews are not fully British, he is using the language of classic pre-war European anti-Semitism. “He has legitimised the public expression of hate, and where he leads, others will follow.  “Now, within living memory of the Holocaust, and while Jews are being murdered elsewhere in Europe for being Jews, we have an anti-Semite as the leader of the Labour Party and Her Majesty’s opposition.  “That is why Jews feel so threatened by Mr Corbyn and those who support him.”  His comments came amid reports Labour’s ruling National Executive committee could adopt the International Holocaust Remembrance Alliance definition of anti-semitism. The move would mark a change of heart by the Labour leadership which failed to endorse the definition at a previous NEC meeting.  A Labour party spokesperson said: This comparison with the race-baiting Enoch Powell is absurd and offensive.   Jeremy Corbyn described a particular group of pro-Israel activists as Zionists, in the accurate political sense - not as a synonym or code for Jewish people.

title: theresa tries dance school kids
story: NewsTheresa May dancing with school kids in South Africa might be the most awkward thing you've ever seenThe Prime Minister boogied on down with the kids moments after getting off a 12-hour flight from London Heathrow at the start of a three-day trade tripShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy political editor22:06, 28 AUG 2018Updated22:07, 28 AUG 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/news/uk-news/video/theresa-dances-schoolchildren-trip-south-13150321,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,nativeAppBanner:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTheresa May tried to dance with school kids on a visit to South Africa and the result can only be described as painful. The Prime Minister boogied on down with the kids moments after getting off a 12-hour flight from London Heathrow at the start of a three-day trade trip. One onlooker described the 61-year-old Tory leader as “moving side to side” and “bobbing up and down” as she was greeted at a school by a group of pupils performing energetically.  Mrs May smiled and laughed throughout and later joined in with a second dance in her visit to the ID Mkize School in Cape Town.  During a packed assembly, she told youngsters: “Can I thank all those young people who were involved in the performances outside who welcomed me?”    The PM used her visit to announce a scheme to boost foreign students' education would be opened up to 100 more of “Africa’s brightest young people”.  The Chevening Scholarship enables students from 144 countries and territories judged to have leadership qualities to undertake postgraduate study or courses in UK universities. “What I see before me in this hall today is the future of South Africa,” said Mrs May.

title: beggar urges passers give him
story: NewsBeggar urges passers-by to give him money instead of food so he can feed crippling alcohol addictionMatthew McNamara is a self-confessed alcoholic who gets through 20 bottles of Lambrini and a bottle of vodka each dayShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAlex GroveKaty Clifton16:28, 28 AUG 2018Updated16:35, 28 AUG 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/news/uk-news/video/beggar-urges-people-give-him-13152968,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A homeless man sleeping on the streets has urged people who pass him to forget food donations and instead give him money to help feed his alcohol addiction.  Matthew McNamara, also known as 'Matty', is a self-confessed alcoholic who can often be found curled up inside a sleeping bag outside a local Sainsbury's. The 42-year-old, who has previously been called aggressive and persistent, is currently subject to a Criminal Behaviour Order which bans him from begging.  Mr McNamara is still urging people to help him fund his crippling alcohol addiction because he suggests the booze is keeping him alive, Hull Live reports.  Every day, the beggar gets through 20 bottles of Lambrini and one bottle of vodka, which he suggests helps him numb the physical and mental pain of homelessness. Without a drink, he says he ends up sprawled out on the floor suffering from seizures.  Mr McNamara, who grew up in Sutton and has a wife who lives nearby, told Hull Live: “I get blind drunk to blot out the suffering and pain I’m in. I’m a broken man and just a shadow of what I was. I used to be a big man with a lot of power but now I’ve got nothing left. “I end up absolutely hammered to the point where I don’t know what’s going on and I do just drink to forget. “It’s dangerous for me to go without alcohol. If I do, I end up in fits and it’s scary. The booze is keeping me alive and it’s what I live for.” Security guards who stand on the door at Sainsbury’s keep a watchful eye on Mr McNamara, who has been banned from entering the store and buying alcohol. He now goes elsewhere with his money to purchase booze and he has implored passers-by not to give him food as it will just go to waste. People are offering to buy me food but I am knocking it back,” Mr McNamara said. “Don’t waste your money because I will just give it to the next man. “I get given lots of food but I don’t eat it – I just give it away. I understand why people might not want to give me any money – I totally get it but I am very forthcoming. “Someone the other day asked me if I wanted food and I said I wanted a beer so she just walked off. I totally get it and I think it’s disgraceful, outrageous and disgusting and people think I’m scum but this is what I have been driven to.  In recent weeks and months, Mr McNamara, who has been intermittently homeless for a decade after resorting to selling drugs, has dabbled in the mind-bending drug Spice. He says he became known as the “spice zombie” after an appearance on TV but just four days ago he was convinced to stop taking Spice in order to retain his spot outside Sainsbury's. “Spice is everywhere in Hull. If you want it you can get it and it’s cheap as chips. It’s &pound30 or &pound40 for an ounce or a tenner for a gram. “I would have a pipe and crash out, wake up, have another and then crash out again. That was my day and it got to the point where I thought ‘I can’t possibly do this anymore.’ “The people in Sainsbury’s didn’t like it and they said I was intimidating customers so I stopped. It had to be done because it was giving me a bad reputation.”

title: cinemas shops businesses across uk
story: AdvertorialWhy cinemas, shops and businesses across the UK are finally allowing the public to use their toiletsDomestos has launched a campaign urging firms to open up their facilities to allShare&nbspByDave Masters12:59, 28 AUG 2018Updated17:45, 28 AUG 2018AdvertorialWe are supporting the Use Our Loos campaign, powered by Domestos"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIt's no laughing matter when you’re out with a child who is suddenly caught short and there’s not a loo in sight. The struggle to track down a clean toilet can lead to tantrums and tears of frustration – and that’s just the parents! Families aren’t the only ones who suffer: elderly people out and about, taxi drivers, freelance workers and, of course, posties can all be affected too. We often take it for granted that there will be a loo about, but over the last 18 years the number of council-run public toilets in the UK has fallen from 3,084 in 2000 to 2,290 in 2018. That is a drop of nearly 800. Councils want to keep public conveniences open, but a typical toilet block costs between &pound12,000 and &pound15,000 a year to maintain and, with substantial reductions to budgets, they have had to make tough choices about where they spend their money.  It means locating a loo can often end in failure and, not surprisingly, it’s driving people round the bend. That’s why we are supporting the new campaign by Domestos, which is encouraging businesses across Britain to let people use their lavatories. The Use Our Loos campaign aims to tackle the demise of public toilets, and asks shops, cafes, restaurants and bars to offer the use of their facilities to the community – to improve availability and stop the problems that a lack of loos can cause.  It benefits the public AND businesses as public loos are important to local economies. Having safe, hygienic toilets can attract more visitors to towns and villages, and increase footfall at a time when the high street is being crippled by closures.  Domestos has a long and much-praised history of helping to give people access to cleaner and safer toilets, partnering with UNICEF for the last six years to create provision for people living in areas without adequate sanitation across the globe. With initiatives including money from Domestos bottles marked with UNICEF* going towards funding, UNICEF and Domestos have already helped more than 10 million people access cleaner, safer toilets. And they are going to help 10 million more. But Domestos realises it’s not just a problem which affects developing countries – it’s an issue here as well, so it’s turning its attention closer to home too. At its worst, a lack of public toilets can force people to stay at home for fear of finding themselves in an embarrassing situation, resulting in social isolation and difficulties in their everyday lives. At best, it creates a massive inconvenience and can spoil an otherwise happy family day out. That’s why Domestos believes that a clean, safe toilet should be within everyone’s reach in the UK – and so do we!
